etymology.description: 为(為) (wèi, "for") provides a context or reason, and 什么(什麼) (shénme, "what") asks a question or seeks further information. Combined, 为什么(為什麼) (wèishénme) asks for the reason or purpose behind something, essentially translating to "why".
etymology.interpretation: 为什么(為什麼) (wèishénme) is used to inquire about the reason or purpose behind an action or situation. It reflects the use of questions in Chinese to seek understanding.

parts.english: for; on account of; because of
what; what kind of; how many

examples.chinese: 你为什么生气(你為什麼生氣)？
他问我为什么不参加(他問我為什麼不參加)，我不知道(我不知道)。
examples.pinyin: Tā wèn wǒ wèishénme bù cānjiā, wǒ bù zhīdào.
examples.english: He asked me why I didn't participate, and I didn't know.
